Want to know more?
Get Started
Dosing Guidelines

Pick the alleles:
Dosage Calculator

Pharmacogenomics aims to predict how individual genetic variability impacts drug absorption, metabolism, and activity. While one treatment approach may work well for one individual, the same approach may not be effective or may cause adverse drug effects in other patients.
The field of pharmacogenomics combines both pharmacology and genomics to develop safe and effective medications along with proper dosages that should be customized to variations in one\'s genes.
How to use this clinical decision support tool
* Humans are over 99% identical at the DNA level.
* DNA mutations, which are any change in a DNA sequence away from normal, account for this 1% difference
* An individual has two alleles per gene
Did You Know:
Why Individuals May Respond Differently to Medications

* Polymorphism is a type of DNA sequence variation that is common in a population.
 
 * There is no single gene that is regarded as standard, but in reality, there are two or more equally acceptable alternatives.
 
 * Several polymorphisms are largely responsible for the differences between how humans respond to drugs.
 
 * The most common type of polymorphism is called a single nucleotide polymorphism, or SNP (pronounced ‘snip’). An SNP results from a single change in a single nucleotide.
 
 * Other types of polymorphism include: more than one nucleotide change, an entire gene insertion or deletion, or ‘extra copies’ of a gene.

* A pharmacogenetic test refers to the individual’s genetic test 
 
 * The study of pharmacogenomics assesses all aspects of the genome to identify variations in the genome that impact drug metabolism and response. 
 
 * Pharmacogenomics encompasses both inherited genome variations that affect the way we metabolize different drugs, as well as somatic variations of the tumor cell that can be used to guide treatment via tumor markers. These latter types of tests are referred to as Targeted Cancer Therapy.

*Variations of one’s genetic profile can change the function of proteins that interact with a drug as well as the drug target.\n \n *Polymorphisms are generally categorized into four groups based on which alleles the individual carries:

*Poor metabolizers (inhibitors)
 *Intermediate metabolizers
 *Extensive metabolizers (normal)
 *Ultra-rapid metabolizers (inducers)
Types of Pharmacogenetic Tests
* Drug-disposition: Genes can alter the pharmacokinetics of a drug
-Pharmacokinetics is the study of the bodily absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion of drugs.
* Drug-target: Genes can change the pharmacodynamics of a drug.
-Pharmacodynamics is the study of the course of action, effect, and breakdown of drugs within the body.
Parent/Active Drug vs. \n Pro Drug
Parent/Active Drug: Formulated with the active form of the drug \n \n Pro Drug: Formulated in its inactive state and must be broken down by enzymes in the body to produce active metabolites.

There are many different companies that offer clinically actionable pharmacogenetic tests to help providers target treatment and medications based on the patient’s genetics. \n \n Many of these tests are now covered by Medicaid/Medicare and private insurance companies.
Ordering a Pharmacogenetic Test
*This is not an exhaustive list, and no endorsement of any company is given.
*This information compiled within this application utilizes evidence-based guidelines published by the Clinical Pharmacogenetics Implementation Consortium (CPIC).
*This is a project that culminated from a partnership between PharmGKB and the Pharmacogenomics Research Network (PGRN).
*CPIC publishes standardized, evidence-based, peer-reviewed, publicly available, non-profit gene/drug guidelines for how to use genomic data to perform prescribing.
Evidence-Based Sources
Educational Resources

Pharmacogenomics Education Program (PharmGenEd™): This is an evidence-based program for healthcare professional and students that is designed to disseminate educational materials related to pharmacogenomics.

Implementing GeNomics In PracTicE (IGNITE): This NIH-funded network is comprised of several different healthcare and research sites that was initiated to find ways to incorporate genomic information into the electronic medical record and create clinical decision support tools. This network has created the SPARK Toolbox, which is a publicly available database for genomic medicine resources for healthcare providers and researchers.
